Little Saint James Island: Epstein's Private Paradise

Seventy-five acres of pristine Caribbean real estate, surrounded by turquoise waters and accessible only by boat or helicopter. Little Saint James was Jeffrey Epstein's refuge - a place where he could escape scrutiny and host guests far from prying eyes. But this paradise harbored dark secrets.

Location and Geography

Little Saint James (often called 'Little St. James') sits in the southeastern waters of St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands. Key geographic features include:
  • Size: Approximately 75 acres
  • Location: Off the coast of St. Thomas, USVI
  • Access: Private boat dock and helicopter pad
  • Visibility: Visible from nearby islands and passing boats
The island's location in U.S. territory made it subject to American law - though its isolation made enforcement difficult. Locals on St. Thomas could see activity on the island but had little insight into what was happening there.

The Compound: A Self-Contained World

Epstein built a self-sufficient compound on Little Saint James:
  • Main House: A sprawling residence with multiple bedrooms
  • Guest Villas: Separate accommodations for visitors
  • Staff Quarters: Housing for the workers who maintained the property
  • Utilities: Its own power generation and water desalination
  • Security: Surveillance systems and restricted access
The compound was designed to function independently, allowing Epstein to host guests for extended periods without outside contact. Workers on the island were required to sign strict non-disclosure agreements and were reportedly forbidden from looking at Epstein directly.

Life on the Island

Former workers and visitors have described the island's operations:
  • Young women were frequently seen on the island
  • High-profile guests arrived by private boat and helicopter
  • Epstein often walked around shirtless or in casual attire
  • Staff maintained strict protocols and discretion
The atmosphere was described as both luxurious and strange. The island had all the trappings of a billionaire's retreat, but something felt off to those who observed it closely. Young women appeared and disappeared. Powerful men came and went. Questions were discouraged.

The Structure Called 'The Temple'

Perhaps the most photographed and speculated-about structure on Little Saint James was a square building with a dome that some called 'the temple.' The structure featured:
  • A blue-and-white striped facade
  • A gold-colored dome
  • Ornate doors with decorative patterns
  • Foundation suggesting underground space
Theories about the building's purpose varied wildly. Some speculated it was used for illicit activities. Others suggested it was simply a library or music room. The truth remains unclear, but the building became a symbol of the island's mystery and Epstein's eccentricity.

The Island After Epstein

Following Epstein's death in 2019, the island became the subject of intense scrutiny:
  • FBI Raid: Federal agents searched the island for evidence
  • Lawsuits: The estate faced claims from the Virgin Islands government
  • Sale: Listed for $125 million, sold for $60 million in 2023
The buyer, billionaire Stephen Deckoff, stated plans to develop the property. For many, the island will always be associated with Epstein's crimes, regardless of its future. The physical structures remain - monuments to a dark chapter that the world is still trying to understand.
Little Saint James was more than a private island - it was Epstein's sanctuary, where he could operate beyond the reach of normal scrutiny. The island's beauty stood in stark contrast to the allegations of what happened there. Today, it serves as a physical reminder of how wealth and isolation can shield wrongdoing, and how long it can take for the truth to emerge.
